The War Views of Pres. Remsen and Prof. Vincent.
There is nothing more interesting to the
readers of the popular magazines of Japan
than the views of porminent Americans on
the Russo-Japanese conflict.
The leading
article in the current issue of the most widely circulated monthly of Nippon, the Tokio
Taiyo (Sun), is a case in point. It is entitled "The War Views of President Remsen
and Professor Vincent of the Johns Hopkins
Uniitersity," and was contributed by Mr.
K. Morimoto, who is now a student at the
Hopkins. The article not only contains the
views of these prominent Baltimore educators, but their photographs. The photograph
of Dr. Remsen is reproduced here just as it
appears in the Taiyo.
"It is," writes Mr. Morimoto, "a source
of great pleasure to know that so far Japan
has won almost all the battles in this great
war with Russia, and it augurs well for the
future.
But it is interesting to observe
how, since war was declared, America and
Europe view the conflict.
"At the Johns Hopkins University everyone is, of course, well informed as to Japanese history, manners and customs. here
everyone, with the exception, perhaps, of
a single Russian student, is strongly proJapanese. Even President Remsen, who is
known from one end of Nippon to the other
as a chemist and scientist, and whose textbooks on organic and inorganic chemistry
are studied in every Japanese college and
university, does not attempt to conceal his
enthusiasm over the Japanese successes at
arms. But it must be remembered that,
while Dr. Remsen is primarily a scientist and
head• of one of the greatest Universities of
the world, he is at the same time a man of
warm heart, great personal magnetism and
deep human interest, and it is this that endears him to the students.
. `!In a conversation with President Remsen

a few days ago he spoke most interestingly
of our Island Empire and the war we are
waging with Russia. 'Japan,' he said,'wants
to expand, and this is necessary because of
the dense population of the islands; but Russia, too, wants an ice-free port in Manchuria.
Both countries moving in the same direction
made war inevitable, and now that it has
come, there are many reasons why I should
like to see Japan the victor. But I am
naturally prejudiced in favor of the Japanese because so many of your prominent
men have been educated at the Johns Hopkins. Among the first to come here was Dr.
Kuhara, then Drs. Mitsukuri, Sato, Motara,
Nakaseko, Nitohe—all Ph. D.'s of this institution. Many others have been students
here, but these men I know well, and from
them I hav,e learned to admire the Jap, not
only as a student, but as a man. I have .
no unfriendly feeling toward Russia, but the
very fact that these and other students of
your nationality have been identified with
the Hopkins and-have been diligent students
and have taken their degrees here makes me
feel, as it were, that they are the children of
our University. It may not be scientific or
rational to think this way, and it is certainly
not impartial, but the same thing may be
said of patriotism.

HOPKINS AT ST. LOUIS.
The exhibits of the University and Medical
School in the Education and Social Economy
Building at the World's Fair, as usual, is
superior to the other college and university
exhibits. While these other institutions devote much space to pictures of the buildings,
athletic teams, etc., the Hopknis exhibits
show the work that is being done in the
University. The Medical School has a fine
set of pictures of the investigations carried
on there; the geological department, although its main exhibit is in the Mines and
Metallurgy Building, is, nevertheless, briefly,
but well represented. The physical laboratory has exhibited a number of Prof. Rowland's machines, together with several of
his diffraction gratings—the one with twenty
thousand lines to the inch being the msot
noteworthy.
In addition to these exhibits, all the publications of the University are to be seen.

Several other small exhibits, including that
of the Semitic department are also exhibited.
An important omission is that of the chemical department. Although this department
has now more students than any other department in the University, no attempt has
been made to show the magnificent work
now being done here in that line.
Another thing which perhaps most of the
Hopkins students visiting this exhibit have
noticed is that there is no book in which to
register. This may seem a small matter to
some, but, nevertheless, it would have been
made good use of if it had been there.

THE ANNUAL RUSH.
The rush between the Junior and Freshman classes, on the first day of the new
collegiate year, has hitherto been an illegal
and forbidden amusement which the classes
engaged in at their peril, knowing that the
college authorities would use every means
to enforce quiet in the University's precincts. As a result, the struggle, broken
off in one place, often renewed itself at a
safer distance from the University. Even
here, armed intervention was a probability,
and the contest was apt, therefore, to reach
an unsatisfactory and inconclusive termination, each side feeling that if it had been
allowed to fight it out, the result would have
been highly gratifying and most honorable
to itself. In addition to this disadvantage,
there was offered to the public of Baltimore
the edifying spectacle of a busy thoroughfare blocked by a struggling melee in which
were mingled a large number of young gentlemen who proceeded to throw each other
about violently, and to denude each other
of important garments; a squad of more or
less helpless policemen who rushed aimlessly
around the outskirts arresting bystanders
and inoffensive freshmen who preferred to
stand on the edge of the fight and look on.
All this display was very undesirable, of
course. When "the Hopkins gets to Homewood" all these little affairs can be settled
respectably and privately on the spacious
campus. At present, however, we lack that
valuable field for operations, and some way
has to be found to make up for its absence.

This year, therefore, it was decided to
authorize the affair and allow it to be held
privately in the cage, thus avoiding publicity, and the overworking of the police in
order to keep the sidewalks open.
The
whole business with its status established
came off without a hitch. The gymnasium
walls shut out the public, and the two classes
settled their accounts with each other in
decent privacy, while the seniors present saw
to the proper conduct of things, and stopped
the fight when it had gone far enough. It
is probable that the same arrangement will
be made next year, since it worked so well
this time. Of course, the dirty floor of the
cage is not as good to roll on as the grass'
of the Homewood campus, but it is certainly
an improvement on the brick pavement of
Howard Street. As a temporary expedient
the cage is certainly very satisfactory. In
time the University will offer greater convenience, for such affairs.

EDITORIAL.
As will be noticed, the NEWS-LETTER
makes its first appearance for the academic
year in an entirely new cover. The question of a new cover has been before the
Board for some time—in fact, the subject
was broached last spring. Owing to the
paper's loss in the fire, however, it was decided to get along with a plain one until
the end of the year.
Several other features which we hope will
be for the best interests of the NEWS-LETTER
will also be noticed. We believe the paper
should have a larger circulation among the
Medical students, the graduates, and the
alumni of the University than at present.
For this reason, we have secured representatives in the first two departments who have
promised to contribute anything of interest.
For the alumni notes, we are dependent upon
charity. If the alumni would bear in mind
that charity begins at their Alma Mater, the
column would doubtless be much longer.
They are urged most strongly to send in any
alumni notes at any time this fall.
The Board loses two excellent men—both
of them hard and consistent workers. Mr.
Murkland has been especially close to the
Editor and the latter wishes to thank him in
the name of the Board for his hearty cooperation. Mr. Baetjer has had a no less

responsible position in looking out for the
financial end of the NEWS-LETTER, and has
always had the welfare of the paper at
heart.
The retirement of these two men leaves
two vacancies; one of the assistant businessmanager, and one of assistant news-editor.
Both places are open to students in the
Freshman and Junior classes. Several men
are already trying for these places; out of
the large Freshman class there ought to be
a larger number than ever trying for the
two places. There will be another vacancy
next month and several more at Easter, when
the NEWS-LETTER passes into the hands of
the present Junior class.
The apathy of the athletic board towards
football, at least, and from talk heard around
the University towards baseball, we judge,
is a thing of the past. All who are acquainted with the athletic situation will acknowledge that there is great difficulty to be surmounted in re-establishing these sports on
a firm foundation; yet the NEWS-LETTER
firmly believes that what has been done this
fall could and should have been done over
a year. ago. For this reason, it is perhaps
fortunate, a new board in sympathy with
this go-ahead-spirit has been elected.
That the new board, if it push forward
the project vigorously, will have the goodwill and support of the majority of students
is very evident from the discussion on the
subject heard around the University.
It is too early to say anything about baseball, but the football season—late as the
movement for a team took definite shape—
has already opened. A fairly good schedule
has been made out, considering that the management had to accept what dates it could
get.
Mr. Janney and the other gentlemen who
are taking an active interest in this new
movement are the kind of alumni that the
University needs. Their support means a
great deal to the success of the teams, and
it is to be sincerely hoped that their interest
is the beginning of an active campaign in
other fields. ,

THE ADVANTAGES OF BEING ON
THE NEWS-LETTER.
N every large college there is a magazine
of some sort, dependent on the students
for contributions. In its _columns are
to be found a summary of the activities of
the students; athletics, musical clubs, college
happenings—all these claim notice. Most of
this class of news is collected by the reportorial staff of the magazine; the literary
part, such as editorials, poetry, etc., is left
entirely to the editorial staff, and students,
unconnected with the magazine, seldom, if
ever, contribute. On the part of the editors
it is a question of getting copy; on the part
of the outside student, it is merely a question of a little extra work, and if the result
is meritorious, he has the undeniable pleasure
of seeing his work in print.
Of course, training is necessary to be able
to write an article possessing interest to the
student reader. A scholarly paper on some
abstruse subject won't "take" half as well
as an amusing incident, cleverly told. In fact,
humor and clever expression are indispensable features of a successful article. The
only way to acquire this training is to practice.
There are two fields for practice open to
the average undergraduate. Most students
know by the end of their freshman-year what
is one of the ways. But that practice is
devoted to polite literature and to rhetoric.
The other field is the college-paper. If undergraduates would write up every "grind"
and happy thought that occurred to him in
a day, the editors would find that selection
instead of copy-writing would be their chief
worry.
The training derived from a little practice
now and then, with the subsequent disappointment of having one's manuscript returned, thereby spurring one to higher efforts, would be invaluable to many a future
"Hullabaloo" editor. I am sure that if more
men contributed to the NEWS-LETTER, it
would not be necessary for "Hullabaloo"
editors to write most of the "stuff," and
much of the conventionality of a college
year-book would be lacking. As it is, most
of the work is done by a few men, and the
work is often on the same lines.
The magazine offers an opportunity for

THE ANNUAL RUSH.
The rush between the Junior and Freshman classes, on the first day of the new
collegiate year, has hitherto been an illegal
and forbidden amusement which the classes
engaged in at their peril, knowing that the
college authorities would use every means
to enforce quiet in the University's precincts. As a result, the struggle, broken
off in one place, often renewed itself at a
safer distance from the University. Even
here, armed intervention was a probability,
and the contest was apt, therefore, to reach
an unsatisfactory and inconclusive termination, each side feeling that if it had been
allowed to fight it out, the result would have
been highly gratifying and most honorable
to itself. In addition to this disadvantage,
there was offered to the public of Baltimore
the edifying spectacle of a busy thoroughfare blocked by a struggling melee in which
were mingled a large number of young gentlemen who proceeded to throw each other
about violently, and to denude each other
of important garments; a squad of more or
less helpless policemen who rushed aimlessly
around the outskirts arresting bystanders
and inoffensive freshmen who preferred to
stand on the edge of the fight and look on.
All this display was very undesirable, of
course. When "the Hopkins gets to Homewood" all these little affairs can be settled
respectably and privately on the spacious
campus. At present, however, we lack that
valuable field for operations, and some way
has to be found to make up for its absence.

This year, therefore, it was decided to
authorize the affair and allow it to be held
privately in the cage, thus avoiding publicity, and the overworking of the police in
order to keep the sidewalks open.
The
whole business with its status established
came off without a hitch. The gymnasium
walls shut out the public, and the two classes
settled their accounts with each other in
decent privacy, while the seniors present saw
to the proper conduct of things, and stopped
the fight when it had gone far enough. It
is probable that the same arrangement will
be made next year, since it worked so well
this time. Of course, the dirty floor of the
cage is not as good to roll on as the grass'
of the Homewood campus, but it is certainly
an improvement on the brick pavement of
Howard Street. As a temporary expedient
the cage is certainly very satisfactory. In
time the University will offer greater convenience, for such affairs.

EDITORIAL.
As will be noticed, the NEWS-LETTER
makes its first appearance for the academic
year in an entirely new cover. The question of a new cover has been before the
Board for some time—in fact, the subject
was broached last spring. Owing to the
paper's loss in the fire, however, it was decided to get along with a plain one until
the end of the year.
Several other features which we hope will
be for the best interests of the NEWS-LETTER
will also be noticed. We believe the paper
should have a larger circulation among the
Medical students, the graduates, and the
alumni of the University than at present.
For this reason, we have secured representatives in the first two departments who have
promised to contribute anything of interest.
For the alumni notes, we are dependent upon
charity. If the alumni would bear in mind
that charity begins at their Alma Mater, the
column would doubtless be much longer.
They are urged most strongly to send in any
alumni notes at any time this fall.
The Board loses two excellent men—both
of them hard and consistent workers. Mr.
Murkland has been especially close to the
Editor and the latter wishes to thank him in
the name of the Board for his hearty cooperation. Mr. Baetjer has had a no less

responsible position in looking out for the
financial end of the NEWS-LETTER, and has
always had the welfare of the paper at
heart.
The retirement of these two men leaves
two vacancies; one of the assistant businessmanager, and one of assistant news-editor.
Both places are open to students in the
Freshman and Junior classes. Several men
are already trying for these places; out of
the large Freshman class there ought to be
a larger number than ever trying for the
two places. There will be another vacancy
next month and several more at Easter, when
the NEWS-LETTER passes into the hands of
the present Junior class.
The apathy of the athletic board towards
football, at least, and from talk heard around
the University towards baseball, we judge,
is a thing of the past. All who are acquainted with the athletic situation will acknowledge that there is great difficulty to be surmounted in re-establishing these sports on
a firm foundation; yet the NEWS-LETTER
firmly believes that what has been done this
fall could and should have been done over
a year. ago. For this reason, it is perhaps
fortunate, a new board in sympathy with
this go-ahead-spirit has been elected.
That the new board, if it push forward
the project vigorously, will have the goodwill and support of the majority of students
is very evident from the discussion on the
subject heard around the University.
It is too early to say anything about baseball, but the football season—late as the
movement for a team took definite shape—
has already opened. A fairly good schedule
has been made out, considering that the management had to accept what dates it could
get.
Mr. Janney and the other gentlemen who
are taking an active interest in this new
movement are the kind of alumni that the
University needs. Their support means a
great deal to the success of the teams, and
it is to be sincerely hoped that their interest

THE ADVANTAGES OF BEING ON
THE NEWS-LETTER.
N every large college there is a magazine
of some sort, dependent on the students
for contributions. In its _columns are
to be found a summary of the activities of
the students; athletics, musical clubs, college
happenings—all these claim notice. Most of
this class of news is collected by the reportorial staff of the magazine; the literary
part, such as editorials, poetry, etc., is left
entirely to the editorial staff, and students,
unconnected with the magazine, seldom, if
ever, contribute. On the part of the editors
it is a question of getting copy; on the part
of the outside student, it is merely a question of a little extra work, and if the result
is meritorious, he has the undeniable pleasure
of seeing his work in print.
Of course, training is necessary to be able
to write an article possessing interest to the
student reader. A scholarly paper on some
abstruse subject won't "take" half as well
as an amusing incident, cleverly told. In fact,
humor and clever expression are indispensable features of a successful article. The
only way to acquire this training is to practice.
There are two fields for practice open to
the average undergraduate. Most students
know by the end of their freshman-year what
is one of the ways. But that practice is
devoted to polite literature and to rhetoric.
The other field is the college-paper. If undergraduates would write up every "grind"
and happy thought that occurred to him in
a day, the editors would find that selection
instead of copy-writing would be their chief
worry.
The training derived from a little practice
now and then, with the subsequent disappointment of having one's manuscript returned, thereby spurring one to higher efforts, would be invaluable to many a future
"Hullabaloo" editor. I am sure that if more
men contributed to the NEWS-LETTER, it
would not be necessary for "Hullabaloo"
editors to write most of the "stuff," and
much of the conventionality of a college
year-book would be lacking. As it is, most
of the work is done by a few men, and the
work is often on the same lines.
The magazine offers an opportunity for

illustrators, so that when a call for illustrations for a "Hullabaloo" is made, the
editors won't find it necessary to utilize
outside help in a student publication. There
would be also more of a representation of
the whole school in such a "Hullabaloo"
than in the case of recent class books.
The NEWS-LETTER offers an opportunity
for the development of untrained talent.
The editors,' I am sure, will be thankful for
all contributions whether they use them or
not. Let every man try to write one article
to the NEWS-LETTER so that when the "Hullabaloo" editors call for contributions they
will be embarassed by the quantity and not
ashamed of the quality.
